section-block.rac_essential-question: What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Quinina Hoyos and illustrated by Donald Wu
section-block.rac_book_summary: In this book, the author shares fact-filled riddles. Clues are given in rhyming text, along with beautiful realistic illustrations. Readers turn the page to find the answer to the question, “What am I?”

section-block.rac_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64304-6. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. What Am I? by Quinina Hoyos, illustrated by Donald Wu. Copyright © 2021 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Yy and Zz Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Show all the pictures. Say: Y is for yo-yo. I spy a yo-yo. Who can show me what I spy? Continue. Then show all the letters and play “I Spy.”

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to sing “The Ants Go Marching.” Vary the song with other animals and movements. For example, “The birds go flying one by one.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read What Am I? written by Quinina Hoyos and illustrated by Donald Wu.
Pablo is excited about reading this informational text about real animals. He can’t wait to see the pictures of amazing animals.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
Which animals in this book have feathers?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s listen as I read the clues. Look carefully at the pictures for clues, too. Then we can figure out what this animal is. What animal do you think we’ll see on the next page? (MB)
This animal tells us that it has eight arms. Eight arms are a feature of this animal. Can you guess what animal this is?
Feathers are a feature of all birds. What can you tell me about this eagle’s feathers and wings?
Let’s spread our arms out wide and pretend to flap our wings.
Look at this quetzal. What do you notice about its feathers?
I see the letter z in the word quetzal. Who can come and point to the z in quetzal?
A turkey has feathers that unfold! Let’s pretend our fingers are the turkey’s feathers as we fold and unfold them.
section.rac_body-text: Open and close your fingers in a fan shape.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I see the letter y in the word turkey. Who can come and point to the letter y in turkey?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question: Which animals in this book have feathers?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud a short sentence that describes a particular animal feature, as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What other birds can you name?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Research shows that children learn the letters of the alphabet best when instruction focuses on five things: letter name, letter sound, phonological awareness, letter in printed text, and letter formation.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Develop Working Memory
section-block.rac_body-text: Explain that when we use our working memory, we remember information to use later. Working memory can help us remember steps in a game or what happens at the beginning of a story. If our goal is to draw a picture of an eagle, we can use our working memory to remember clues from the book we read to help us draw it.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to talk about the Mind Builder and use our working memory as we reread What Am I? The book was written by Quinina Hoyos and illustrated by Donald Wu.
Clifford listens carefully for clues and uses his working memory to help him answer the question, “What am I?”

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions. Read aloud the book and the Day 2 prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: There is a question at the bottom of the page. It says, “What am I?” The question ends with a question mark.
Let’s listen to the clues and look at the picture. This animal says, “I have a hard shell that protects me.” That’s a really good clue! What other clues does it give? Which animal is talking? (MB)
Look at that amazing blowhole! Which animal is talking? Let’s make a prediction!
I see that the clues rhyme. I’ll read a clue, and you say the missing rhyming word. (MB)
section.rac_body-text: Read page 15, pausing to let children fill in said and walk.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What clues did this animal say? Let’s use our working memory to keep them in mind as we figure out what animal this is. (MB)
Remember, our goal is to use the clues to help us figure out what animal is talking.
What a great picture clue! It’s a dorsal fin! Let’s be sharks and bend our elbows behind us to make a dorsal fin. (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Challenge children to use their working memory by repeating growing sequences of animal sounds. Invite children to sit in a circle. Chant together: “Animals! Animals! We all make sounds.” Then say, “Quack like a duck.” Children make quacking sounds. Repeat the chant and then call out another animal’s sound. Children should say the new sound and repeat the previous animal’s sounds in sequence. Continue until children are repeating five animal sounds. Then start again.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about a favorite animal feature.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Working memory is an important Executive Function skill that powers much of our learning and behavior. Working memory helps us remember and use information for short periods of time. It helps children follow directions to complete a task, remember story details while a book is being read aloud, remember numbers while counting, and much more! (Understood.org/8 Working Memory Boosters)

section-block.rac_body-text: Choose two animals that have the same features. Invite children to describe their features.
Lead children in singing different variations of “Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes.” For example, “Head, shoulders, paws, and tails,” or “Head, body, fins, and scales.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread What Am I? written by Quinina Hoyos and illustrated by Donald Wu.
What Am I? is an informational text filled with fun facts about animals. Pablo loves to think about facts he already knows about animals and learn new facts about them.
This is the guiding question that I want you to think about as we read: What features help animals stay safe?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions. Have conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This snail uses its shell to protect itself. How does it use its shell to stay safe? (MB)
An octopus lives in the water. The water is its habitat. Don’t scare an octopus! What will the octopus do if it gets scared?
The armadillo has a shell to protect it. What other animals use their shells to stay safe?
The jaguar has dots called rosettes. What questions might we ask about the jaguar?
This chameleon can change its skin color to match its habitat. What color should the chameleon turn when it wants to hide in the grass? On a dirt path?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question: What features help animals stay safe?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: An octopus uses its ink to stay safe.
A snail uses its shell to stay safe.
A chameleon changes its color to stay safe.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about an animal’s feature that helps it stay safe.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: A snail hides in its sh________ (shell).
A snail hides in its shell.
How are a snail’s shell and an armadillo’s shell the same? How are they different?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Open-ended questions are questions that can’t be answered with yes or no, and that do not have a right or wrong answer. Open-ended questions encourage conversation and higher-order thinking. They also help create a positive classroom environment!

section-block.rac_body-text: Encourage a discussion about the animals children have learned about this week. Discuss each animal’s unique features.
Invite children to use their imaginations and move like the animals they read about! Call out an animal name and have children move like that animal.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Fantastic Feet. It is an informational text.
Pablo loves to learn about different animal features! Fantastic Feet shows pictures of a wonderful animal feature—their feet!
What Am I? and Fantastic Feet each focus on amazing animal features. Let’s see what’s the same about these two texts.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show What Am I? book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about our concept question:
What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, then use these prompts to read and discuss the child-facing poster together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I see a snail. How can we tell how many feet this snail has? The word foot lets us know that there is only one.
How many feet does the ostrich have?
Use your working memory and tell in what way this ostrich is like the eagle, quetzal, and turkey we saw in What Am I? (MB)
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show What Am I? book cover.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at the cat’s feet. Use your working memory. How are this cat’s feet like the jaguar’s feet we saw in What Am I? (MB)
I see the letter f in a lot of words on this poster. Who can help me point to the letter f?

section.rac_body-text: Lead children in a line around the room, as you all move around like different animals. Chant “Flap, flap, let’s be eagles,” or “Waddle, waddle, let’s be ducks,” or “Jump, jump, let’s be cats.”
Provide a writing prompt about a special animal feature and guide children’s responses.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Showing children how ideas in one text are similar to ideas in another helps them improve comprehension. They can begin to make meaning of facts and start to understand that learning is interconnected. The facts they learn about animals, for example, are not random. All animals have unique features and characteristics that help them survive. Children can begin to make comparisons based on facts found in different texts.

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to pretend they are explorers. Have them use pretend binoculars to study an animal’s features. Ask them to describe the animals they see on their journey. Encourage children to name the different features of each of the animals they see. You might ask: How many legs? Does the animal fly? Does the animal swim? What features does it have to protect itself?
Introduce new vocabulary that will be used today.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book What Am I?, written by Quinina Hoyos and illustrated by Donald Wu.
Pablo the Parrot loves to read informational text! This book has clues, and it’s fun to read. Who remembers if this book tells a story or teaches us things?

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
Which animal feature would you like to have if you could have one?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who would like to be a bee today?
section.rac_body-text: Invite a child to act the part of a bee, buzzing around the room.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Powerful jaws are a feature of an ant. Can you show me your powerful jaws?
section.rac_body-text: Move your jaw down and up.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s pretend we are armadillos who curl into a ball in our shells.
Let’s pretend we are dolphins and make clicking noises.
section.rac_body-text: Model making clicking noises with your tongue. Then invite children to ask the question, “What am I?”
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s pretend we are chameleons who catch bugs with our long tongues.
section.rac_body-text: Model flicking your tongue to catch a pretend bug.
Give a moment for a Turn and Talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Which animal feature would you like to have if you could have one?
section.rac_body-text: Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: A long tongue like a chameleon.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about an interesting animal feature that they learned about this week.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Would you like to have a blowhole like a dolphin?
I would like to have a bl________ (blowhole) like a dolphin.
I would like to have a blowhole like a dolphin.
What other features are good to have if you live in water?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children benefit when objects are labeled in both English and their home language. Learn the translation of common items or use the Internet for translation. To introduce target vocabulary, display a large animal poster and label common features, such as feet, head, neck, eyes, and so on.
